awd_abstract_narration:
Graph theory is a central research direction in combinatorics. Graphs are abstract mathematical objects that have been extensively used to model problems in different subjects, such as in network theory, integrated circuit design, and scheduling theory. A general approach for solving problems on complicated graphs is to first decompose the original graph into more tractable pieces, solve the problems on those pieces, and finally construct the answer for the original graph from the answers for those smaller pieces. Different problems require different decomposition techniques and many decomposition theorems have been developed and successfully applied to solve long standing conjectures. However, it is unclear whether those developed decomposition theorems are sufficient to solve other open problems. The purpose of this project is to address this fundamental issue by developing new structure decomposition theorems to enrich the toolkit and applying them and other developed theorems to solve major conjectures in graph theory and theoretical computer science. This project includes many research problems that are suitable for graduate students and advanced undergraduate students. Progress made on this project will advance knowledge in mathematics and contribute to education.

The aim of this project is to prove new decomposition theorems and apply them to solve open problems in graph theory and computer science. An objective is to prove a global tree-like decomposition theorem for graphs in immersion-closed families and apply it to solve an open problem related to a conjecture of Abu-Khzam, Langston, Lescure and Meyniel on graph coloring. In addition, a recent newly developed notion for layered tree-decomposition will be considered in order to generalize algorithmic results on minor-closed families to strictly wider classes of graphs, such as graphs embeddable in a fixed surface with some crossings allowed. Another objective of this project is to solve a conjecture of Dvorak and Norin on island decomposition which is motivated by a strengthening of a relaxation of Hadwiger’s conjecture on coloring graphs in minor-closed families. The strategy for attacking the above problems is to further investigate the structure of graphs, where new ideas will be involved, and the PI's earlier results and other structure theorems in the literature will be exploited.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many research problems in science and engineering, such as the ones in geometry, network theory, and integrated circuit design, can be modeled by graphs. Graphs are abstract mathematical objects studied in combinatorics addressing vertices and the connection between vertices. This project develops decomposition theorems about graphs and studies their applications. They offer tools to reduce problems on complicated graphs to problems on simpler graphs. This project provides opportunities for training students via research cooperation and enriches material for outreach activities toward general audience and K-12 students.

This project focuses on graphs that do not contain certain substructures. These kinds of graphs are widely studied in combinatorics, geometry and theoretical computer science.

One decomposition theorem developed in this project is about graphs that exclude an arbitrarily fixed graph as an immersion. A theorem obtained in this project shows that under a mild condition, every such graph can be decomposed into small pieces, where each small piece is essentially a graph that do not have enough vertices adjacent to sufficiently many other vertices.

The aforementioned decomposition theorem is used to prove an Erdos-Posa type result, which is related to the packing problem and covering problem studied in combinatorial optimization. This result states that the solutions of the packing problem and covering problem for graph immersions in graphs satisfying a mild condition are tied to each other.

Another result obtained in this project is another Erdos-Posa type theorem about topological minors, which are substructures related to topological containment. This result proves a conjecture of Thomas and implies that even though the solutions of the packing problem and the covering problem are known to be not tied to each other, relaxing the integral solution of the packing problem to be half-integral can ensure the tied connection.

A series of results conducted in this project are about partitioning graphs into small pieces, where each piece has bounded size, breadth, or depth. Those results are closely related to a conjecture of Hadwiger proposed in 1940s on coloring graphs with a forbidden minor, addressing the minimum possible number of pieces in such decompositions.

The case for bounded breadth is completely solved in this project, which shows that the minimum number of pieces is determined by the connected tree-depth of the forbidden minors. This result confirms a conjecture of Ossona de Mendez, Oum, and Wood.

The case for bounded depth is also solved in this project, which leads to applications in metric geometry and computer science. This result shows that the number of required pieces is essentially determined by the planarity of the forbidden minors, solving a number of open problems in the literature.

The study for the case for bounded size in this project is addressed in terms of the topological containment, which is more general than the minor containment. A result in this project provides a linear upper bound for the number of required pieces.

Another part of this project studies degeneracy, which is a sufficient condition that implies the existence of a partition into graphs with no edges.

One result in this direction is about random graphs. This result determines the threshold probability of random subgraphs of graphs in various minor-closed families for satisfying the degeneracy condition. This result can be applied to the graphs satisfying certain topological properties.

Another result proves an optimal bound for the minimum degree, which is the dual of the degeneracy, for forcing the existence of cycles with specific lengths. This result resolves a number of conjectures proposed by various scholars since 1980s at once.

The research outcomes obtained in this project enrich the outreach events organized in the PI's department and the new graduate topic courses developed and taught by the PI. The PI delivered lectures and led activities in various events aimed to K-12 students and undergraduate students, including underrepresented minorities, based on simplifications of some of those research results. The material developed by the PI for those activities can be reused by other scholars or students in the future. The research outcomes obtained in this project were presented in international and domestic conferences and seminars to promote collaboration and interaction with the research community.
